title.narrative: African Girls Can CODE Initiative (AGCCI), engagement

description.narrative: with the African Girls Can Code Initiative, UN Women and ITU intend to increase the number of women across Africa who choose education and careers within coding and ICT.

participating-org.narrative: United Nations Entity for Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Women

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

title.narrative:
Output 3.1: Girls that have participated in the Coding Camps are able to approach tech clubs, tech companies and CSOs working within ICT and Coding.
Note:- for reporting purpose indicator 3.1.C is used

Indicator 3.1.A: Number of young girls with established contacts to tech clubs, tech companies and CSOs
Indicator 3.1.B: Number of tech clubs, tech companies and CSOs listed by organizers (listing will include specific contact persons at each club, compa-ny and CSO)
Indicator 3.1.C: Number of girls organising Open houses and showcasing their skills at the exhibition

comment.narrative:
3.1.A: Baseline: TBD by Pre-Questionnaire for participants at the Coding Camps Target 2022: 100% of participating girls at Coding Camps Source: Pre- and Post-Questionnaire for participants at the Coding Camps
3.1.B Baseline: 5 companies, 5 clubs and 5 CSOs per country Target 2022: 10 companies, 10 clubs and 10 CSOs per country Source: Database of clubs, companies and CSOs, developed under AGCCI.
3.1.C Baseline: Zero girls Target 2022: 1000 girls across Africa and 800 Ethiopian girls Source: Coding Camp reports
NOTE :- Indicator 3.1.A: Three tech clubs have been identified and linking girls with the tech clubs will take place during Phase II of the programme Indicator 3.1.B: The activities related to this indicator are planned to be implemented during the Phase II of the programme.

title.narrative:
Output 3.2: Role models - including male role models - from different sectors (teachers, entrepreneurs, artists, politi-cians, community leaders etc.) are encouraging young girls and women to access an education and career within ICT and coding.
NOTE:- for reporting purpose indicator 3.2.A is used

Indicator 3.2.A: Number of role models that have committed themselves to the AGCCI campaign and are visible (appear in the media)
Indicator 3.2.B: Number of male corporate leaders who promote (with public statements reg. corporate policy promoting gender diversity) a di-verse workforce under the AGCCI campaign
Indicator 3.2.C: Number of HeForShe champions from the ICT sector

comment.narrative:
3.2.A Baseline: Zero Target 2022: 5 in each participating country Source: Information from the professional media bureaus and AGCCI cam-paign database tracking role models, leaders and champions
3.2.B Baseline: Zero Target 2022: 5 in each participating country Source: Information from the professional media bureaus and AGCCI cam-paign database tracking role models, leaders and champions
3.2.C Baseline: Zero Target 2022: 5 in each participating country Source: UN Women tracking of HeForShe Champions and AGCCI campaign database tracking role models, leaders and champions
NOTE:- Indicator 3.2.B: Information not available. It will be measured in the campaign to be conducted in Ethiopia during phase II.
Indicator 3.2.C: The activities related to this indicator are planned to be implemented the following year

title.narrative: Outcome 3: Young girls and women seek employment through connections with key actors in the ICT sector

Indicator 3.A: Number of young girls and women accessing tech clubs listed in database
Indicator 3.B: Number of young girls and women employed by the tech companies listed in the database
[Indicator no. drawn from overall result framework]
Note from UNWomen regarding ourcome result:- Once the database is finalized 2021 it will include more contacts from tech clubs, tech companies and tech CSOs, Via the online platform the girls will be informed of new contacts and opportunities in their home country.

comment.narrative:
3.A Baseline: TBD by Pre-Questionnaire to the listed tech clubs Target 2022: Baseline + 20% Source: Pre- and Post-Questionnaire to the tech clubs listed in the AGCCI database
3.B Baseline: TBD by Pre-Questionnaire to the listed tech companies Target 2022: Baseline + 20% Source: Pre- and Post-Questionnaire to the tech clubs listed in the AGCCI database
Note from UNWomen regarding baseline:- Database has not been finalized in 2020 as it was postponed to 2021. For the 2021 Annual Work Plan the activity is included.

title.narrative: Output 1.3: Young girls and women are inspired by media to choose education and career within coding and ICT
Indicator 1.3.A: Number of girls citing media and/or role models as their inspiration

comment.narrative:
Baseline: TBD by Pre-Questionnaire at first five Coding Camps
Target 2022: Baseline + 40% measured with pre-questionnaires at the last five Coding Camps Source: Pre-Questionnaire for participants at the Coding Camps
NOTE:- The activities related to this indicator are planned to be implemented during the next reporting period. However, in the post questionnaire of the national coding camps, 93% of the participants found role models in ICT.

title.narrative: Output 1.1 Young girls have in-creased skills in digital literacy, coding, and personal development through Coding Camps across Africa

Indicator 1.1.A: Young girls will have increased skills to be builders and en-trepreneurs. For example young girls indicate that they are feeling equipped with digital literacy, coding and personal development skills

comment.narrative: Baseline: Zero participants Target 2022: 90% of participants feel equipped at the end of each camp Source: Pre- and post-assessment among participants at camps

title.narrative: Output 1.2: Young girls have confidence in ICT and coding and feel that they are able to overcome prejudice and traditional gender roles
Indicator 1.2.A: Confidence level of young girls in ICT and Coding

comment.narrative: Baseline: Zero participants Target 2022: All participants feel confident after attending camp Source: Pre- and post-assessment among participants at camps based on confidence testing at similar coding camps, such as TechKobwa camps in Rwanda.

title.narrative: Outcome 1: Young girls are access-ing educations and careers within coding and ICT

Number of girls entering higher education in ICT and coding
Note:- The project lifetime is 2018-2022 and has implementation Plan of two phases covering four years from April 2018 to April 2022. Phase I (April 2018 – June 2019) was implemented with funds committed by the Kingdom of Denmark. Therefore, the reporting on the results covers the period (April 2018 –December 2019) and the 2018 activities related to most indicator were planned to be implemented in the 2019 reporting period.
Note from UNWomen regarding outcome result:-- As the AGCCI coding camp trains young girls between the age of 16- 19 who are still in high school it would be a bit difficult determine the number of young girls that have entered higher education in ICT and coding.

comment.narrative:
TBD by national education statistics at programme inception. Target 2022: Baseline + 20% Source: National education statistics
Note from UNWomen regarding baseline:- No data was found from the national statistics to determine the number as the National education statistics doesn’t have that kind of data.
